#Codes from Paul Mooney (visualization of most common words)

%matplotlib inline
def plotWordFrequency(input):
    f = open(Haiti,'r')
    words = [x for y in [l.split() for l in f.readlines()] for x in y]
    data = sorted([(w, words.count(w)) for w in set(words)], key = lambda x:x[1], reverse=True)[:40] 
    most_words = [x[0] for x in data]
    times_used = [int(x[1]) for x in data]
    plt.figure(figsize=(20,10))
    plt.bar(x=sorted(most_words), height=times_used, color = 'red', edgecolor = 'black',  width=.5)
    plt.xticks(rotation=45, fontsize=18)
    plt.yticks(rotation=0, fontsize=18)
    plt.xlabel('Most Common Words:', fontsize=18)
    plt.ylabel('Number of Occurences:', fontsize=18)
    plt.title('Most Commonly Used Words: %s' % (Haiti), fontsize=24)
    plt.show()

By Lioman Lima - BBC World News

As if a large-scale earthquake, cholera, dengue, hurricanes, lack of water, poverty, poor health, malnutrition, violence, political instability, corruption and insecurity were not enough, Haiti now faces the same enemy as the rest of the planet: the coronavirus.

On the night of Thursday, March 19, the poorest nation in the western hemisphere registered the first two cases of covid-19 and has since decreed a state of emergency to try to prevent the spread of a pandemic that in the world has left more than 20 thousand dead. Until the 28th, there were 8 confirmed cases in the country.

'This pandemic kills twice': the pain of families prohibited from burying their dead.
"Schools, vocational training centers, universities will be closed from March 20, 2020.

The Caribbean country, which is still trying to recover from an earthquake that devastated what little there was in 2010, closed its borders and canceled almost all flights two weeks ago to contain the virus.

#The poorest country

Before the arrival of the coronavirus and even before the earthquake - which made Port-au-Prince a pile of rubble, killed more than 316,000 people and left more than 1.5 million homeless - Haiti had long been the poorest nation in the world. Western Hemisphere.

The 2010 earthquake, two-thirds of its 10 million inhabitants were already living in extreme poverty and without access to drinking water. After the earthquake, a cholera outbreak that has now become endemic left about 10,000 dead.

Now, after a decade and in the midst of social instability that even led to the death of police officers by the military, the Caribbean country may be facing a bigger problem. https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=https://www.bbc.com/portuguese/internacional-52055474&prev=search&pto=aue

#The great uncertainty

The great concern about the arrival of the coronavirus in Haiti transcends poverty, which will multiply the contagions, or the lack of health infrastructure, which will result in a terrible number of deaths.

It is the first time that the country is at risk of being left alone in the midst of an epidemic that could decimate its population.

"All countries that remembered Haiti at critical times are now trying to fight the pandemic in their territories, so I am afraid that Haiti will have to face this pandemic alone,"

"Now, they are concerned that they may continue to receive the external support and medical supplies they need, not only for covid-19, but to continue maintaining the services that they have been able to offer so far,"

They cannot minimize the circumstances. Haiti faces a challenge never seen before.

"So many people living in overcrowded houses, without running water or soap, unable to stock up on food and eat if they don't work ... The cholera epidemic was predictive (of what could happen now): Haiti has gone through everything is bad in its history. The nightmare will be worse than that of Italy "

The scenario could be even worse than in other nations, given the high levels of poverty and ill health.

"It's a country where the majority of the population lives well below all poverty standards, in an infrastructure that has been virtually destroyed," 

"Other epidemics have shown that the most affected parts are those where the most vulnerable people live and that is why the coronavirus is of great concern, because the largest number of the Haitian population lives in poverty"

The high rates of malnutrition or the high number of immunosuppressed people, with HIV or even with tuberculosis, make the population at risk comparatively more vulnerable than in most nations of the world.

Haiti is the country with the highest number of AIDS cases in the Caribbean and its HIV prevalence rates are among the highest in the region. In addition, it also has the highest incidence of tuberculosis across the continent and 22 per cent of children under 6 years of age suffer from severe malnutrition.

In addition to all this, one of the greatest dangers is that the disease will become uncontrollable in a country where the health system does not provide the basics.

"One of the things that worries them most is that this disease (covid-19) has resulted in a collapse of health systems around the world and, in the case of Haiti, this is no longer enough in everyday life,"https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=https://www.bbc.com/portuguese/internacional-52055474&prev=search&pto=aue

#A system at the limit 

To get an idea of the impact that the coronavirus can have on the country, just remember what health services were like even before the pandemic arrived.

"Until now, receiving medical services has been very difficult for the majority of the population. Many people need to travel from one part of the country to another for hours to the few existing hospitals to receive care. There are pregnant women who currently need to travel from a city to another to have a cesarean section "

There is no official data on the number of hospitals currently operating in Haiti or the number of health professionals, although, according to the local press, both have been decreasing in recent years.

A 2018 report by the St Luke Foundation and the Maryland Medical Center showed that year, across the country, there were only 90 beds for intensive care. The country has 10 million inhabitants.
